author: Simon Robb for Metro.co.uk
title: Inside the Australian cult where children were injected with LSD and locked up
text:
The notorious cult had 20 blond-haired children (Picture: Label Distribution) Children were injected with LSD and held locked up for two decades by a woman who claimed to be Jesus Christ reincarnated. 
Anne Hamilton-Byrne collected 28 blond-haired children to create a ‘master race’ and prepare for an apocalyptic war that never came.
Gardener 'on the run after having sex with a client's dog' has been found The delusional leader of the Australian sect, The Family, now lives in the dementia wing of a suburban Melbourne nursing home.
But back in 1963, she started the notorious cult with British psychiatrist Raynor Johnson, where children were subject to starvation, beatings and drugging.
A documentary , airing in Australia later this month, lifts the lid on the cult with chilling accounts from Hamilton-Byrne herself.

Anne Hamilton-Byrne told people she was Jesus Christ reincarnated (Picture: Label Distribution) The children were injected with LSD (Picture: Label Distribution) They were locked away from society for 20 years (Picture: Label Distribution) Speaking about her brood of identical children, she said: ‘I wanted them to look like brothers and sisters — I must admit this.
Porn star notorious for Nazi tattoos arrested in meth raid ‘I loved them in their little smocks and jeans and the long hair and ribbons. It was beautiful. It was lovely to see.’
When confronted about their cruel treatment, she added: ‘I love children.’
Born Evelyn Edwards worked as a yoga teacher when she first met Johnson.
Just a year later, the pair preached to parents about a new religion that combined elements of Christianity and Hinduism.
Children were also subject to starvation and beatings (Picture: Label Distribution) Anne and her husband Bill with one of the children (Picture: Label Distribution) She met Raynor Johnson in the early 60s (Picture: Label Distribution) Dealing LSD, they were able to convince these parents to hand over custody of their children to build an ‘elite race’ at a secluded property in Lake Eildon, Victoria state.
Man 'who groomed 13-year-old girl for sex' wears balaclava in court The children were put through a sickening initiation of taking LSD and sitting in a dark room.
But the police were alerted to the abuse when one of the children, Sarah Hamilton-Byrne, was expelled in 1987 for her rebellious behaviour.
Now other Lake Eildon children have come forward to talk about their harrowing experiences.
Ben Shenton claimed he witnessed Sarah brutally beaten with a belt.
Children were told to prepare for an apocalyptic war (Picture: Label Distribution) Anne now lives in a dementia wing of a nursing home (Picture: Label Distribution) Detective Lex said he regrets not bringing Anne to justice (Picture: Label Distribution) ‘Sarah was thrashed. I was watching her being belted with a buckle and she’s being beaten to the point where she’s wriggling out of her clothes,’ he said.
In 1987 police raided the home and rescued six of the children before the couple fled.
Trump adviser Kellyanne Conway told she 'makes no sense' The two were eventually captured, but were only handed £3,000 fines for falsely registering three of the children.
The cult still exists to this day but the numbers are said to be dwindling.
Detective Lex de Man, who led the investigation, said: ‘My only regret is she was never held totally to account for the misery she caused to the former cult children.’
The documentary aired on BBC4 in November 2016, but will air in Australia on February 23.
